revised_title: Auto-agglutination of Red Blood Cells in Trypanosomiasis: Mechanism and Significance
tldr: This study investigates the auto-agglutination of red blood cells in trypanosomiasis and its relation to temperature. The researchers demonstrate that temperature plays a crucial role in the development of the phenomenon, with agglutination occurring more readily at lower temperatures. They also find that the serum of infected animals contains auto- and iso-agglutinins, which contribute to the agglutination process.
